author: MATTHEW BENNS
title: Bill Shorten fronts royal commission hearing into trade unions corruption | The
text:
LABOR leader Bill Shorten has been admonished and his credibility as a witness questioned as he repeatedly avoided answering questions at the royal commission into trade union corruption in Sydney today.
Commissioner Dyson Heydon said he was concerned about Mr Shorten’s credibility as a witness and warned him to give “proper” answers as he faced questions over his deals as union boss.
Mr Shorten was being quizzed over $300,000 in “bogus” payments from building companies that secured union co-operation on the giant Melbourne EastLink project.
But he continually offered long and convoluted answers that failed to answer specific questions about invoices.
“A lot of your answers are non-responsive,” Commissioner Heydon said.
“Some of your answers are responsive, but then add something that isn’t responsive.”
He added: “What I am concerned about more is your credibility as a witness. A witness — and perhaps your self interest as well.”
Commissioner Heydon warned Mr Shorten that it was in his self-interest to concentrate on “giving a proper answer”.
Mr Shorten replied: “I’m conscious of the commissioner’s advice that if we want to be here two days, move along and answer questions.”
Bill Shorten (top left) has taken the stand for a second day. Source: Supplied
Mr Shorten has endured a tense second day in the stand following yesterday’s revelation that he had failed to declare a $40,000 donation from 2007 to his election campaign until two days before the hearing.
The hearing began with Mr Shorten being quizzed over a $100,000 a year deal — over three years from 2005 to 2008 — paid by building giants Thiess John Holland when Mr Shorten was Victorian and national secretary of the Australian Workers’ Union.
The union issued a string of invoices to the engineering contractors for ads in their union magazine, training and dinner dances to make up the payments.
Senior Counsel Assisting the Commission Jeremy Stoljar said the invoices were being issued with “no regard” whether the events and services had “actually been provided.”
One invoice for $30,000 was for research done on “Back Strain in Civil Construction Industry” but no research has ever been provided.
“Is this a bogus invoice that’s claiming payment for work that was never done?” Mr Stoljar asked.
Mr Shorten replied: “I would never be party to issuing any bogus invoices, full stop.”
He said a lot of the dinner dances for union delegates had taken place because he had attended most of them.
“I wouldn’t be doing my job if I was asking workers to pay for their own tickets to a dinner dance or to pay for their own health and safety representative training for instance when I can get a company to do it,” Mr Shorten said.
Senior Counsel Assisting Jeremy Stoljar: “Is this a bogus invoice claiming for work never done?”
Bill Shorten: “I would never be party to issuing bogus invoices, full stop.”
Mr Shorten defended his enterprise bargaining in the EastLink deal, telling the commission the agreement delivered a 16 per cent wage rise, including 11 per cent superannuation, for union members.
Mr Stoljar asked why Thiess had agreed on top of this to pay the series of $100,000-a-year instalments.
“It is of no surprise, nor is it untoward, if a company is being further engaged after the EBA is signed,” Mr Shorten said.
“And I am very confident that in my time as leader of the AWU in Victoria that if we were sending out invoices for services, my expectation is that work would be done consistent with the invoices rendered.”
Bill Shorten arrives hours early for the royal commission this morning. Picture: John Grainger Source: News Corp Australia
Mr Shorten was also accused of having “a conflict of interest” over an EBA he negotiated with a Victorian company called ACI Glass.
The EBA did not include any reference to almost $500,000 being paid to the AWU for a “paid education levy” over two to three years.
Mr Shorten conceded the paid education levy had been an “oral agreement” with ACI but had not been included in the EBA he was negotiating at the same time.
Mr Stoljar said Mr Shorten had a “serious conflict of interest” negotiating an EBA and a side deal with the same company.
Mr Shorten said it was not a conflict of interest because “we were negotiating very good conditions and the members and delegates and organisers were negotiating excellent conditions for glass workers at Spotswood.”
He said the AWU would have liked to have had the levy in the EBA but if the employer was not prepared to include it the issue was “not something you were prepared to stop the production lines for.”
Mr Shorten revealed in the hearing on Wednesday he had failed to declare a donation from a labour-hire company ahead of the 2007 federal election.
The $40,000 donation from Unibuilt was not declared until Monday this week.
Unibuilt later donated money through the Australian Workers’ Union that was used to fund Mr Shorten’s campaign director Lance Wilson between February and November 2007.
Mr Wilson, known to Mr Shorten as a member of Young Labor, was however listed on the books of Unibuilt as a “research officer”.
The company was at the time negotiating an enterprise bargaining agreement with the AWU, of which Mr Shorten was national secretary.
Senior Counsel Assisting the Commissioner Jeremy Stoljar SC during the royal commission into trade union governance and corruption in 2014. Picture: Paul Harris Source: News Corp Australia
But the Labor leader on Wednesday denied claims he used his position as national secretary of the AWU to his own advantage, as he sought to win the Victorian federal seat of Maribyrnong.
Mr Shorten rejected Mr Stoljar’s suggestions that he had only declared the donation because he was “waiting to see whether this would emerge in the royal commission”, despite knowing about it for months.
Other MPs, including Prime Minister Tony Abbott, had updated their disclosures in recent years, Mr Shorten said.

Former Labor minister and union boss Greg Combet has been acting as an adviser with Mr Shorten’s legal team.
Following Wednesday’s grilling, Mr Combet praised the federal Labor leader’s performance.
“I think he’s been very upfront about it all,” Mr Combet told reporters in Sydney.
But not every ALP member was as supportive of Mr Shorten.
Former ALP national secretary Bob Hogg called for the Labor leader to quit in the wake of his royal commission appearance.
“Bill, do something for the ALP. It is simple. Just go,” Mr Hogg wrote on social media on Wednesday night.
The hearing continues.
